titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:15. Davis— Gideon—with a plough for Genl. La Fayette
Davis, with Letter from Corby, Norfolk. to be Light-symbols Florida.
Brent. Daniel with
Robertson, Consul at Tampico.
Wilson John—of Louisiana. Complaints agt.G. Davis Survr. Genl.
Balmain— Andrew— symbols P. Johnson—to be cadet or midshipman
Adlum to see Genl. La Fayette, who was gone out.
Borbridge— T. P.M. Kingston Luzerne Co. Pa. to see Genl. La Fayette.
Mercer— Coll. going to Alexandria & near Leesburg.
Smith— Constantine—going on leave of absence to N York
Clay— H— State Department business— Somerville. Poinsett &c
Southard— S. L— Navy business— Stewart’s trial. the Genls. departure.
Syon—dined here— Genl. La Fayette &c at Commodore Morris’s.
2. VI: Walk to Georgetown— 1 hour— No bath.
Adlum— introduced to Genl. La Fayette— We go to his vineyard symbols
Randolph son of D. M. Randolph—introduced by Genl. La F.
Southard S. L. with proceedings of two Court-Martials— Medn.
Brent. Daniel—with
Gurnell—to be appointed assistant Librarian to Congress— refd.
Hindman Coll. wishes to know who will be appointed Coll. 2d. Arty
Ringgold— T. Marshal. Arrangements for this Eve and next Wednesday.
Syon dined with us. Evening party to meet Genl. L. F. Mrs A. ill
3. V:15. Walk to and round the Capitol Square. 1 hour. 30 minutes. symbols
Southard S.N. with proceedings of Court Martial on Stewart
With La Fayette to Adlum’s— Met Dupont and Porter
Brown— Genl. with Macomb’s opinion upon Brevets.
Rush— R. S.S. gave him papers concerning M. L. Hill, for Report
Southard with Sentence of Court Martial on Stewart.
Evening writing.
4 V:15. Sun rose at 5:37. as on the 8th. of April. Matthew 17

list.item: Southard. S.N. breakfasted with us— Genl. La Fayette at Genl Brown’s

div.p: 5. V:30. An hour’s walk.
Southard— S. L from 7. A.M. to 6 P.M. Documents of Stewart’s trial
Southard breakfasted and dined with us.— Then came with
Morton— Edmund and deputed from the Corporation of New-York.
Cowdrey.
Clay— H— Somerville’s Instructions. Also for Commodore Rodgers
Rush— R— Report in case of M. L. Hill. Complaints against Collectors.
6. V:15. Sun rose 5:30. Walk to the river one hour— Matthew 19.

list.item: With Genl. La Fayette to the Capitol— Saw the copy of his portrait and Capellano’s and Causici’s and Persico’s works.

div.p: Company to dine—40 persons.— Eve with G. W. La Fayette
7. V:30. Walk to the river—an hour Matthew
Brown— Genl. with La Fayette to see Stewart. Southard Letter from Stewart.
Somerville— W. C. goes in the Brandywine
La Fayette. Genl. took leave of him— Procession Civil and Military to the Steam-boat— Address and Answer.
Rush— R. returned from the boat— Evening rain.
Idle remainder of the day.
8. VI:15— An hour’s walk— Matthew 20.21.
Rush— R. Secy Treasury— J. B. Swanton’s answers to the charges of M. L. Hill—complaints against Hamilton, Collector Pensacola.
Recommendation of Coll. Aspinwall, and of J. A Smith.
At dinner Gallaher, from Harper’s ferry, with a letter recommendatory from Wever—for place of paymaster there.
9. IV:45— Walk to the river— No Bath. Matthew 23.
Hodgson. for employment
Byrne— Mrs. with a Bill for Scarfs and Truncheons
Foster—upon the affair of Bennett Ex Consul at Pernambuco
Cortildi—an Italian Physician sometime resident at N.Y.
Anderson R. C. Minister to Colombia, now on his return to Bogota—
Macomb— Genl. with
Swartwout; Robert—lately from New-York. a visitor
Clay— H—introducing
Caravadossy— Ignazio Vincenzo. Chevr.—Consul General from Sardinia.
Huygens & family—Madam, Son & daughter. visits to Mrs Adams
Coxe Proceedings of Court Martial on Ramage— M’Kenney’s claim
Evening—John returned from the Brandywine
10. V:15. Sun rose at 5:44. Walk to Georgetown— Matthew 24.
Scott. Alexander. recommends Wilson as Collector at Pensacola
Kent— Dr— Returned from the Brandywine—going home.
Brown— Genl—also returned, much pleased with the tour.
Bainbridge— Commodore—the same. thinks the ship now in Gulph Stream
M’Kenney— T. L. brought three impressions of M. Fürst’s Medal
Stewart— Commodore, visit— Recovering from illness. with him was Ward a Midshipman during his cruize in the Franklin
Elgar—with Letter from N. Biddle about the Bank furnace
Evening. Anderson— R. C.—going to-morrow for New-York.
11. V:15. Sun rose 5:45.— Over the tall poplar tree. N. of Treasy
Heard Little. Romans 12.15.
Baker. 2. Thessalonians 1–7–8.9.10.
Read Johnson— Sermon 20. On Scoffers at Religion—excellent.
Recd. Letter from Govr Troup of Georgia—demanding arrest of Gaines.
12. V:15. Walk to Georgetown. Matthew 26.
Southard. S.N—twice—concerning the Court Martial on Ramage symbols
Worthington of Ohio comes from Saratoga Springs.
Foster. upon Bennett’s Affair— I had not decided upon it.
Barron. Commodore—returning to Norfolk— Ventilation of Ships
Watkins Dr. with
De Butts— Professor at the University of Maryland.
Clay H—Huygens’s note. Addington going— Troup’s last Letter—
Worthington dined with us. Mrs Adams and Elizabeth unwell.
13. V. Walk to the Bridge and round. 1 hour 15 symbols Matthew 27.
Barbour— James S.W. returned this morning from Va.Genl. Gaines
Southard— S.N. Proceedings of Court-Martial on trial of Ramage.

list.head: Cabinet Meeting on the Letter from Govr Troup demanding that Genl. Gaines should be tried by a Court-Martial— Barbour to draft Letters.

div.p: 14. V:30. Walk to Georgetown. Matthew 28
Southard— Letters from Warrington. Ramages Trial. Stewart. Morris
Barbour— S.W. Drafts of Letters to Troup and Gaines. Broadus Harper’s ferry.
Clay. H. S.S. Forsyth’s claim Letter from K of Netherlands. Bennett’s case
M’Lean— J. P.M.G. Skinner P.M. Baltimore and H. Lee’s case
Brown. Genl. Papers concerning Cummings— Scott and Gaines
Goldsborough R. H— Letter and memorial. Conversn with him.

list.head: for the appointment of Israel Little as Justice of Peace in the 6th. ward.

div.p: Sullivan— G—here in the evening just arrived symbols
15. V— Walk over the Tiber to the Bridge— Mark 1.2
Brent— Dl. minute of Contingent expence forn. intercourse fund Forsyth
Gaer Revy. Soldier, came from N.Y. to see Genl. La Fayette.
Foster—upon Bennett’s affair—referred him to Dept. of State
Adams— Mrs Margaret—a place for her son in Patent Office
Rush— R—his doubts, as to the course taken with Troup and Gaines.
Clay— H—Despatches from R. King— Letter from G. Canning.
Nelson H—returned from Spain— Saw R. King at Cheltenham.
Coles Edward—Govr of Illinois. comes from Saratoga Springs.
Southard—Court Martials on Leggett & Wolbert—going to N.J.
Nelson and Coles dined with us— Excuse from G. Sullivan.
Evening call at Southard’s— Mrs Monroe gone to bed. Comet symbols
Sat up till midnight to see it symbols
16. VI:15. Walk to Georgetown. Mark 3.4

list.item: Sullivan. G—Proposal to stop at R. Stockton’s. Baltimore Steam-Boat.

list.head: Mrs Monroe proposes to proceed to Loudoun tomorrow. Mr Hay says they will not go till Monday. Mrs Ms health much improved by her visit to New-York.

list.item: Graham— George. Resignation of Register L. O. Lexington Missouri
Frye. N. difference with Elgar; pay for city lots— Wheaton’s claim
Cook— T. Allowance for T. J. Hellen, at Cambridge. 400–500.
Rush. Charges against G. Davis— M’Nevens Alcohometer, to Dept.
Southard: decisions on Court-Martials upon Wolbert and Leggett—
Clay. Decision against Bennett. Instructions to R. C. Anderson
Barbour. Preparing Letters to Govr Troup, Genl Gaines & Crowell
Wilton— Alonzo—Subscription for Presbytn. Church Culpeper.
Coxe. R. S. about M’Kenney’s claim— To call to-morrow Morning with Pleasonton.— Browere takes Busts from a plaistered
Thornton Dr mask— Going to Boston to which time I referred
Browere him— Charles goes tosubmit, to-morrow morning

div.p: 17. V. Walk to City Hall Mark 5.6

list.head: Pleasonton admits that M’Kenney was charged twice with a sum of 9810 dollars— Accts to be reexamined

list.item: Baker. to recommend a Mr Gilman for a Clerkship
Scott. A. with Letters laudatory from Mr Madison & Monroe—Peru
Brent. D. with draft to R. C. Anderson—decision on Forsyth’s claim.
Addington— H. U—to take leave—gave him a message to G. Canning.

list.head:
Francis and Ward returning to New-York from Mr Jefferson’s and the University— Mr Jefferson declining
The University prospering

Cabinet Meeting— Letters from Secy of War, to Govr Troup. Genl Gaines and Crowell discussed and determined. Proposal to delay definitive answer, and give notice to Genl Gaines. Not approved— Arrest and trial of Gaines refused

list.item: Sullivan— G. in the Evening— Will call to-morrow Morning—Trippe

row.cell: Wright as Consul at Rio de Janeiro

list.item: Read Johnson’s Sermon 21. Goodness of God.

div.p: 19. V:30— Sun rose 5:55 Mark 9:10.

list.item: M’Lean— J. P.M.G— of J. S. Skinner
Houston—with Letter from my father to T. Truxtun

div.p: Up with Charles till 1. A.M. Seeing Comet and Saturn
20. VI. At half past nine A.M. left Washington with my wife, my Son John, Elizabeth C. Adams, in my own Carriage, and four horses— The Coachman John and groom William

The Stage soon followed with M. A. Giusta and his wife. Mrs Adams was very unwell before we left the City— We stopped half an hour at Ross’s, and dined at Merrill’s at Waterloo at dusk of Evening we arrived at Baltimore, and took lodgings at Barnum’s Hotel— The weather was fair and intensely hot
Mrs Adams’s illness increased the whole day, and she was taken with a violent fever— I sent for Dr Potter who attended, and prescribed for her. We found Mr George Sullivan at Barnum’s
N. Williams, T. Finley, D. Hoffmann, Mr Newman
Mary Buchanan— called on us

21. V:30—Mrs Adams very unwell, but we embarked in the Steam-boat United States, Captain Trippe, who went this time the day passage purposely for us—there were a few other passengers besides G. Sullivan—among them Mr Henry Alexander of Baltimore. We left the wharf at 6:30 and reached Frenchtown at 1. P.M— Mrs Giusta came thence to Newcastle with us in the carriage—and John with Mr Sullivan and Antoine in the Stage—at 4. P.M. we arrived at Newcastle and found the Steam-boat Captain Jenkins in waiting for us they had gone down from Philadelphia on purpose— We left our Carriage and Horses to come on by land, and came up ourselves, in the Steamboat— Reached Philadelphia between 8 and 9 and took lodgings at the Mansion House
Mrs Adams soon retired to bed, ill, with a distressing cough.
We had several visitors in the Evening— Among whom W. Smith of South Carolina and Govr Geddes.

22. V.30.Mrs Adams was ill the whole night, and confined to her bed all this day— Sent for Dr John Hopkinson who came, and bled her twice in the course of the Morning— Very uncomfortably situated at the Inn— numerous visitors— Geddes to converse on politics— Dr. Moore Director of the Mint— R. Peters junr. with whom I went and visited a model of a Railway— Visit from judge Peters— G. Sullivan went to Princeton

23. V.Mrs. Adams continues ill, but apparently so much better that we hope to be able to proceed upon our Journey to-morrow— I called upon Mr Geddes and had a long conversation with him on Carolina Politics. John Hopkinson— The Dr and dined with us— Miss Mease passed great part of the day with Mrs Adams— Peters sent me Strickland’s Reports.
24. V:30.Mrs Adams more severely ill than she has yet been— Changed her chamber— I visited the Mint with Dr. Moore— Mr W. Jones, and Mr Steele the Collector, with many other visitors called.
25. V:15.— Unitarian Church with Mr John Vaughan— Heard Mr Furness
Call at Mr John Sergeant’s. Afternoon heard Mr Bedell from Deut. 33.27

The eternal God is thy refuge and underneath are the everlasting arms—a very impressive discourse— Dr Physic visited Mrs. Adams this day. Says she is convalescent, but will not be able to proceed on her journey for several days— My time is so limited that I concluded to proceed alone to-morrow, if she continues better— The carriage was sent on to Bristol on Friday.

26. VI. Mrs. Adams is still recovering but will yet be several days unable to travel— At noon, leaving my Son John and Elizabeth Adams with her I took the Steamboat to Bristol— There landed, and invited Mr of Baltimore, whom I met in the Boat to go with me to Trenton, which he did. Stopped at Trenton at Bispham’s Tavern— Found Mr and Mrs. G. Sullivan there— Mr Southard was gone over to Bordentown, expecting to meet me there at Mr Hopkinson’s. Dr Holcombe, and many other visitors called upon me, in the hour that I stopped. G Sullivan agreed to go on with me to New-York— It rained all the Evening— Reached Princetown between seven and eight in the Evening— The Inn was crowded with Company— Mr Southard is to deliver an Oration to-morrow to the two united Literary Societies of the College, and the day after is the Commencement. I received many pressing invitations to remain, but proceeded to New-Brunswick where we arrived about eleven at Night— Antoine goes with me.
